metadata.title: Synthesis of Block Copolymer Nano-assemblies via ICAR ATRP and RAFT dispersion polymerization: How ATRP and RAFT lead to difference

Synthesis of Block Copolymer Nano-assemblies via ICAR ATRP and RAFT dispersion polymerization: How ATRP and RAFT lead to difference Shuwen Qu,‡a Ke Wang,‡a Habib Khan,a Weifeng Xiong,*b and Wangqing Zhang*a,c
Block copolymer nano-assemblies were synthesized via initiators for continuous activator regeneration atom transfer radical polymerization (ICAR ATRP) dispersion polymerization employing the CuBr2/tris(2-pyridylmethyl)amine catalyst in an alcoholic solvent at a relatively low temperature of 45 °C. The typical poly(ethylene glycol)-block-polystyrene (PEG-b-PS) nano-assemblies synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization are compared with those synthesized via RAFT dispersion polymerization under other similar conditions. It is found that the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies, e.g., including lamellas, vesicles and vesicular clusters, synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization have much complicated morphologies, which are different from those synthesized via RAFT dispersion polymerization. The reasons leading to the difference are searched, and it is conclusively supposed that the high Ð of the synthesized BCPs and the salt of the copper catalyst used in ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization should be involved. This low temperature initiated ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization is believed to be a valid method to prepare block copolymer nano-assemblies through polymerization-induced self-assembly.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text:
Recently, synthesis of block copolymer (BCP) nano-assemblies by polymerization-induced self-assembly (PISA) has attracted great interest because this PISA strategy affords a very convenient and valid synthesis of highly concentrated nano-assemblies.1-4 Generally, three living/controlled radical polymerization methods include reversible addition fragmentation chain transfer (RAFT) radical polymerization,5-27 atom transfer radical polymerization (ATRP)28-32 and nitroxide-mediated radical polymerization (NMP)3337 are used in PISA. Of all these, PISA employing RAFT is the most widely studied, and various nano-assemblies are synthesized.5-27 ATRP using CuⅠ/ligand system was initially employed in PISA.28-32 However, CuⅠ/ligand has poor solubility in some organic solvents, low tolerance to oxygen and toxicity to biological tissues, which limit its applications.38,39 Recently, ATRP with CuⅡ/ligand catalyst including simultaneous reverse and normal initiation (SR&NI) ATRP,40,41 initiators for continuous activator regeneration (ICAR) ATRP42,43 and activators regenerated by electron transfer (ARGET) ATRP44,45 is achieved, which is more tolerable to oxygen and can lower the Cu catalyst concentration to as less as 10 ppm. Now, this ATRP with CuⅡ/ligand catalyst is also applied to synthesize BCP nano-assemblies under PISA conditions.46-50 In RAFT and ATRP dispersion polymerization, morphology of the BCP nano-assemblies is correlative to the degree of polymerization (DP) of block copolymers,5,6,8,9,11,14,19,20 monomer concentration,5,6,8,14,17,22 and solvent properties,7,15,20,26,31,32 For example, it was revealed, in RAFT dispersion polymerization the poly[(ethylene glycol)]-block-polystyrene (PEG113-b-PS) nanoassemblies converted from nanospheres to vesicles when the polymerization medium changed from methanol to low molecular weight PEG, indicating that solvent played an important role to determine block copolymer morphology.27 Besides, in solution selfassembly, it was found that morphology of polystyrene-blockpoly(acrylic acid) (PS-b-PAA) nano-assemblies changed from spheres, to nanorods, and finally to vesicles when the salt of NaCl was added, and it further changed into large compound vesicles when the salt concentration increased from 11 to 21 mM.51 Hawker and coworkers reported the controllable self-assembly of amphiphiles via metal ion coordination, through which isolated micelles, aggregated particles, and multilamellar vesicles could be obtained.52 Zhu et al. revealed that with the help of transition metal ions, various polystyrene-block-poly(4-vinyl pyridine) (PS-b-P4VP) nano-assemblies could be obtained by emulsion-solvent evaporation.53 Furthermore, it was found that molecular weight distribution or Ð of BCPs exerted somewhat influence on the BCP nano-assemblies.54-56 It is known that in the two PISA formations of ATRP and RAFT dispersion polymerizations, their polymerization conditions are much different, e.g., polymerization temperature,

sections.heading: ARTICLE Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2019, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
presence/absence of catalyst salt, polymerization rate, and etc. However, comparison of block copolymer nano-assemblies via these two PISA formations is rarely made.50
In this contribution, the BCP nano-assemblies of poly(ethylene glycol)-block-polystyrene (PEG-b-PS) were synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization and RAFT dispersion polymerization with very similar conditions, and comparison between these PEG45b-PS nano-assemblies was made. It is found that the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization have much more complicated morphologies than those prepared via RAFT dispersion polymerization. The possible reason leading to the difference is discussed, and the high Ð of BCPs and the copper catalyst in ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization as well as the different nucleation of block copolymers may be involved. Inspired by this, more block nano-assemblies, e.g., poly(ethylene glycol)-block-poly(methyl methacrylate) (PEG-bPMMA), poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate)-block-poly(methyl methacrylate) (PHPMA-b-PMMA) and poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate)-block-poly(benzyl methacrylate) (PHPMA-b-PBzMA), were synthesized through this ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization. This method of ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization is demonstrated to be a promising method to prepare BCP nano-assemblies with complex morphology.

sections.heading: 2.1 Materials
sections.text: Poly(ethylene glycol) monomethyl ether (CH3O-PEG45-OH, Mn = 2000 g/mol, Alfa) was purified by azeotropic distillation with toluene before use. Styrene (St, >98%, Heowns, China), methyl methacrylate (MMA, >99%, Tianjin Chemical Company, China) and methyl 2-bromopropanoate (99%, J&K) were distilled under reduced pressure. Benzyl methacrylate (BzMA, 98%, Alfa Aesar) and 2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate (HPMA, 98%, Heowns, China) were passed through a basic alumina column to remove inhibitor prior to use. S-1-Dodecyl-S′-(α,α′-dimethyl-α″-acetic acid) trithiocarbonate (DDMAT) was synthesized as reported previously.57 2,2'-Azobis(2methylpropionitrile) (AIBN, >99%, Tianjin Chemical Company, China) was recrystallized from ethanol prior to use. 2- Bromoisobutyryl bromide (98%, Heowns, China), 2,2′-azobis(2methylpropionamide) dihydrochloride (VA-044, 99%, J&K), tris(2pyridylmethyl)amine (TPMA, 99%, Annaiji, China), cupric bromide (CuBr2, 99%, Heowns, China) and cupric chloride (CuCl2, 99%, aladdin, China) were used as received. Deionized water was used. All other chemicals were used as received unless otherwise specified.

sections.heading: 2.2 Synthesis of macroinitiators for ATRP
sections.text:
Two ATRP macroinitiators, 2-bromoisobutyryl-terminated poly(ethylene glycol) monomethyl ether (PEG45-Br) and bromideterminated poly(2-hydroxypropyl methacrylate) (PHPMA29-Br), were used in the present study, and their syntheses are introduced below.
Synthesis of PEG45-Br. The synthesis of PEG45-Br was achieved through acylation between CH3O-PEG45-OH and 2-bromoisobutyryl bromide.58 The detail can be found in ESI.
Synthesis of PHPMA29-Br. Into a 25 mL Schlenk flask, HPMA (2.00 g, 13.9 mmol), methyl 2-bromopropanoate (0.0463 g, 0.277 mmol), CuCl2 (0.00448 g, 0.0333 mmol), TPMA (0.0387 g, 0.133 mmol), AIBN (0.0546 g, 0.333 mmol), the internal standard of 1,3,5- trioxane (0.125 g, 1.39 mmol) and 1,4-dioxane (4.0 g) were fed. The reaction mixture was initially degassed by repeatedly cycles of freezing-pumping-thawing, and then the polymerization was performed at 65 °C for 50 mins with 58.2% monomer conversion determined by NMR. The polymer solution was passed over a column of basic alumina and the polymer was precipitated in diethyl ether and dried in vacuum, and then PHPMA29-Br was obtained.

sections.heading: 2.3 Synthesis of the PEG macromolecular RAFT agent
sections.text:
The macromolecular chain transfer agent (macro-CTA) of PEG45-TTC, in which TTC represents the functional trithiocarbonate terminal, was synthesized through esterification between poly(ethylene glycol) monomethyl ether and DDMAT.59 The detail is illustrated in ESI.
2.4 Synthesis of PEG-b-PS nano-assemblies via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization
All examples of ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization were performed under [monomer]0:[macroinitiator]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0:[VA-044]0 = DP:1:0.1x:0.4x:1.0x with 15 to 25 wt% solid content in the MeOH/H2O mixture (80/20, w/w) as shown in Table S1. A typical synthesis of PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies with a targeted DP of the PS block at 300 under [St]0:[PEG45-Br]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:0.6:2.4:6 with 20 wt% solid content was described herein. Into a 10 mL Schlenk flask, St (0.300 g, 2.90 mmol), PEG45-Br (0.0206 g, 0.00967 mmol), CuBr2 (0.00128 g, 0.00577 mmol), TPMA (0.00670 g, 0.0231 mmol), VA-044 (0.0186 g, 0.0577 mmol) and 80/20 MeOH/H2O (1.35 g) were weighed. The mixture was degassed by three freeze-pump-thaw cycles, and then polymerization was performed at 45 °C. After a given time, polymerization was quenched by putting the flask in ice water. The styrene conversion was analyzed by UV−vis spectroscopy as introduced in Supporting Information.60 The PEG45-b-PS nanoassemblies were isolated via centrifugation (12500 rpm, 30 min), washed with MeOH, and dried under reduced pressure to obtain white powder.
Following the similar procedures, nano-assemblies of PEG-bPMMA, PHPMA-b-PMMA and PHPMA-b-PBzMA were also synthesized.
2.5 Synthesis of PEG-b-PS nano-assemblies via RAFT dispersion polymerization
The PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies via RAFT dispersion polymerization were synthesized under [St]0:[PEG45-TTC]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:0.333 with 20 wt% solid content at 45 °C in the 80/20 MeOH/H2O mixture. A typical RAFT dispersion polymerization was introduced below. Into a 10 mL Schlenk flask, St (0.300 g, 2.90 mmol), PEG45-TTC (0.0226 g, 0.00967 mmol), VA-044 (0.00104 g, 0.00321 mmol) and 80/20 MeOH/H2O (1.30 g) were weighed, and the mixture was degassed by three freeze-pump-thaw cycles. Polymerization was performed at 45 °C for a given time and then quenched by putting the flask in ice water. The styrene conversion

was analyzed by UV−vis spectroscopy as shown in Figure S1. The PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies were isolated via centrifugation (12 500 rpm, 30 min), washed with MeOH, and dried under reduced pressure for next characterization. RAFT dispersion polymerization under [St]0:[PEG45-TTC]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:4 in presence of CuBr2/TPMA was also conducted as described in ESI.
2.6 Solution self-assembly of PEG45-b-PS synthesized by ICAR ATRP and RAFT dispersion polymerization
A typical solution self-assembly in the presence of CuBr2/TPMA is described as follows. PEG45-b-PS278 (20 mg, Mw = 32.1 kDa, Ð = 1.19 by RAFT or Mw = 30.3 kDa, Ð = 1.47 by ICAR ATRP) was dissolved in 4 mL DMF solution, which contains CuBr2 (0.0858 mg, 0.000384 mmol) and TPMA (0.446 mg, 0.00154 mmol). The MeOH/H2O mixture (80/20, w/w, 20.0 mL) was added into the mixture slowly, and a stable colloid dispersion was obtained. It was subsequently dialyzed in the MeOH/H2O mixture (80/20, w/w) for 3 days to remove DMF. The resultant block copolymer nanoassemblies (~1 mg/mL) was kept at room for next characterization. Other block copolymer nano-assemblies in absence of CuBr2/TPMA or in presence of CuBr2 and TPMA were prepared with the similar procedures.

sections.heading: 2.7 Characterization
sections.text: 1H NMR analysis was conducted on a Bruker Avance III 400 MHz NMR spectrometer. The polymer molecular weight and distribution were determined by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) on Waters system equipped with Waters 515 HPLC pump, three Ultrastyragel columns and an online Waters 2414 refractive index detector maintained at 35°C. THF was used as the flowing phase (1.0 mL/min), and polystyrene samples as the calibration standards. TEM observation was carried on a JEOL 100CX-II electron microscope at 100 kV or a Tecnai G2F20 electron microscope at 200 kV. A JEOL JSM-7500F Field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) was applied. Varian 100 UV-vis spectrophotometer was employed for analysis.

sections.heading: 3.1 Synthesis of ATRP macroinitiators and macro-CTA of RAFT
sections.text:
The ATRP macroinitiators of PEG45-Br and PHPMA29-Br were synthesized as shown in Scheme 1. PEG45-Br was prepared by the esterification reaction of PEG45-OH with 2-bromoisobutyryl bromide. The acylation degree can be evaluated via comparing the area ratio at δ = 3.37 ppm (a) and δ = 1.93 ppm (c) in Figure 1A, and it is suggested that more than 98% PEG45-OH was converted into PEG45-Br. The molecular weight with narrow dispersion (Mn,GPC = 2680 Da, Ð = 1.04) was confirmed by GPC (Figure 1B).
Scheme 1. Synthesis of PEG45-Br (A), PHPMA29-Br (B) and PEG45-TTC (C).
PHPMA29-Br was synthesized via ICAR ATRP under [HPMA]0:[methyl 2-bromopropanoate]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0:[VA-044]0 = 50:1:0.12:0.4 8:1.2. The polymerization proceeded very fast, and it was quenched after 50 mins with moderate monomer conversion of 58.2% to obtain qualified ATRP macroinitiator, which was confirmed by 1H NMR and GPC (Figure 1). The theoretical molecular weight (Mn,th=4350 Da) can be calculated by the monomer conversion following eq S1. Molecular weight relative to PS standard was analysed by GPC (Mn,GPC = 6220 Da, Ð = 1.13) and the low dispersity indicated the controllable synthesis of PHPMA29-Br.
Figure 1. The 1H NMR spectra (A) and GPC traces (B) of PEG45-Br, PHPMA29-Br and PEG45-TTC.
Following the procedures shown in Scheme 1, the PEG45-TTC macro-CTA for RAFT dispersion polymerization was synthesized by esterification between PEG45-OH and DDMAT. The esterification efficiency of PEG45-OH can be estimated by the area ratio of the signal at δ = 3.37 ppm (a) and the signal at δ = 3.26 ppm (d) in Figure 1A, and it is determined that more than 99% PEG45-OH is converted into PEG45-TTC. The molecular weight of PEG45-TTC (Mn,GPC = 3305 Da, Ð = 1.03 ) was confirmed by GPC (Figure 1B).

sections.heading: 3.2 Synthesis of block copolymer nano-assemblies by ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization and comparison with those by RAFT
sections.text:
The conditions for ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization (Scheme 2) employing the typical PEG45-Br macroinitiator were screened.

Scheme 2. Synthesis of PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies via ICAR ATRP (A) and RAFT (B) dispersion polymerization.
As shown in Table S1, the [macroinitiator]0:[CuBr2]0 ratio was crucial for ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization. Low concentration of the CuBr2 catalyst led to slow polymerization rate and relatively high Ð of block copolymers. With the [macroinitiator]0:[CuBr2]0 decreasing to 1/0.8, polymerization rate reached to maximum and Ð gradually decreased to a plateau around 1.3. Temperature was also important to this ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization, and all the subsequent ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerizations were performed at the optimized temperature of 45 °C.
Figure 2. The monomer conversion-time plot and the ln ([M]0/[M])time plot for the synthesis of PEG45-b-PS by ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization (A), GPC traces (B), molecular weight and Ð (C) of PEG45-b-PS. Polymerization conditions: [St]0:[PEGBr]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:0.6:2.4:6, 20 wt% solid content, 80/20 MeOH/H2O mixture, 45 °C.
The ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization employing the PEG45Br macroinitiator at optimized conditions under [St]0:[PEGBr]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:0.6:2.4:6 at 45 °C was investigated. As shown in Figure 2A, it underwent an initial homogeneous stage before 3 h corresponding to synthesis of PEG45b-PS with a short and therefore soluble PS block and then a heterogeneous stage corresponding to the formation/growth of the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies after 3 h. Accordingly, a ln([M]0/[M]) vs time plot containing two stages corresponding to the homogenous ICAR ATRP polymerization and the heterogeneous one is found, which is very similar with RAFT dispersion polymerization reported
previously.17,27 The synthesized PEG45-b-PS block copolymers were characterized by GPC and NMR (Figure 2B). As summarized in Figure 2C, Mn,GPC and Mn,NMR, which is calculated by comparing the characteristic chemical shift at δ = 3.64 ppm and at δ = 6.30-7.23 ppm corresponding to the PEG and PS blocks, linearly increases with monomer conversion. Mn,NMR is slightly higher than the theoretical molecular weight Mn,th, whereas Mn,GPC is much lower, which is possibly ascribed to the PS calibration standard and the potential residue of the Cu catalyst. The Ð value of the PEG45-b-PS samples locates at 1.14-1.48 (Figure 2C), and it increases with monomer conversion.
Figure 3. TEM images of the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies prepared via ICAR ATRP at 3 h (A), 4 h (B), 5 h (C), 6 h (D and E) and 12 h (F). SEM images of some typical samples are inset at the right bottom of the TEM images. Polymerization conditions: [St]0:[PEG45Br]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:0.6:2.4:6, 45 °C, 80/20 MeOH/H2O mixture.
The PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization at different polymerization times were examined by TEM and SEM. Initially, lamellas of PEG45-b-PS formed at case of low DP of the PS block (Figures 3A and 3B). With increasing DP of the solvophobic PS block, lamellas converted into vesicles probably through lamella scrolling as discussed previously (Figure 3C).61 With the DP of PS block further increasing, vesicular clusters formed (Figures 3D-F). Interestingly, the vesicular clusters could keep stable in the solvent of MeOH/H2O mixture, and no

dissolution was observed even the vesicular clusters were highly diluted to 0.01 wt%. This suggests that the vesicular clusters are kinetically frozen in the solvent at room temperature.
Figure 4. TEM/SEM images of PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies with similar DP of the PS block but different solid contents (A and B) and same solid content but different DP of the PS block (C and D).
Figure 5. TEM images of the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies prepared via RAFT dispersion polymerization at 16 h (A), 22 h (B), 25 h (C) and 35 h (D). Polymerization conditions: [St]0:[PEG45-TTC]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:0.333, 45 °C.
The present vesicular clusters are much different from block copolymer nano-assemblies, e.g., vesicles, reported previously.2 This arouse our interest to clarify how polymerization conditions
affect formation of the PEG45-b-PS vesicular clusters. Figure 4 summarizes the TEM/SEM images of the PEG45-b-PS nanoassemblies synthesized at different targeted DP of PS block and different solid concentration in the ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization. Note: see the GPC traces of PEG45-b-PS in Figure S2. It indicates that vesicular clusters tend to form at either high solid content (monomer concentration) or high DP of the PS block. Otherwise, single lamellas or vesicles formed in ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization.
PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies were also synthesized via RAFT dispersion polymerization. To make comparison, RAFT dispersion polymerization under [St]0:[PEG45-TTC]0:[VA-044]0 = 300:1:0.333 was performed under conditions very similar with ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization, for example, the same polymerization temperature of 45 °C, the same solid content of 20 wt% and the same targeted DP of the PS block at 300. Benefited from the use of the VA-044 initiator, which have a much lower 10 h decomposition temperature than the usually used AIBN (44 °C vs 65 °C), RAFT dispersion polymerization ran smoothly with low copolymer dispersity (Ð = 1.06-1.18) and a linear increase in polymer molecular weight (Figure S3). As shown in Figure 5, single vesicles of PEG45-bPS formed when the DP of the PS block was extended above 84. Clearly, the single vesicles prepared via RAFT dispersion polymerization are much different from those via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization.

sections.heading: 3.3 Possible reasons leading to different block copolymer nanoassemblies by ICAR ATRP and RAFT
sections.text:
In this section, the possible reasons leading to the different PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies in ICAR ATRP and RAFT dispersion polymerizations are discussed. By comparing the above mentioned ICAR ATRP and RAFT dispersion polymerizations, three differences between them can be concluded. First, CuBr2/TPMA were used in ICAR ATRP, whereas they were absent in RAFT. Second, under the present optimized conditions, ICAR ATRP run much faster than RAFT. Note: this does not mean the general trend, and the polymerization rate of ICAR ATRP and RAFT is dependent on polymerization conditions. Third, the PEG45-b-PS synthesized by RAFT has a lower Ð than that by ICAR ATRP in the present study.
Following these concerns, dispersion polymerization employing the PEG45-TTC macro-CTA in the presence of CuBr2/TPMA under [St]0:[PEG45-TTC]0:[VA-044]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0 = 300:1:0.333:0.6:2.4 was firstly checked. This dispersion polymerization was just similar with the RAFT dispersion polymerization except that CuBr2/TPMA were added. It was found that this RAFT dispersion polymerization run very slowly (below 10 % monomer conversion in 48 h) and the mixture did not become turbid in 48 h. This is not surprised, since the VA-044 initiator is oxidized by CuBr2. Hence, dispersion polymerization with much more VA-044 initiator under [St]0:[PEG45-TTC]0:[VA044]0:[CuBr2]0:[TPMA]0 = 300:1:4:0.6:2.4 was performed. As revealed in Figure S4, this dispersion polymerization run with a similar rate with ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization under the optimized conditions, and large-sized thin vesicles (Figure S5) formed. These large-sized thin-walled vesicles are much larger than those by RAFT dispersion polymerization (Figure 5) and much different from ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization (Figure 3). GPC

analysis indicates a bimodal traces and a high Ð of the synthesized polymer. These results suggest that CuBr2/TPMA and Ð of the synthesized polymer are correlative to the morphology of the block copolymer nano-assemblies.
Figure 6. TEM images of the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies formed via solution self-assembly in the 80/20 MeOH/H2O mixture in absence (A and C) and presence (B and D) of 0.6 equivalent CuBr2/TPMA.
To further clarify out the reason, herein solution self-assembly of the pre-synthesized PEG45-b-PS block copolymers in 80/20 MeOH/H2O is investigated. To fulfill this investigation, two PEG45-bPS samples with the similar DP of the PS block but different Ð, e.g., PEG45-b-PS270 (Ð = 1.47, synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerizations) and PEG45-b-PS278 (Ð = 1.19, synthesized via RAFT dispersion polymerizations) were used. In the alcoholic solvent of 80/20 MeOH/H2O, the PS block is insoluble and it forms the core of the micelles, and the PEG45 is soluble and it keeps the micelles suspending in the solvent. To check the effect of CuBr2 and TPMA on the block copolymer nano-assemblies, the nano-assemblies in the alcoholic solvent in absence of CuBr2 and TPMA, in the presence of TPMA, in the presence of CuBr2 and in the presence of CuBr2 and TPMA were prepared and checked by TEM. Note: the molar ratio of CuBr2/TPMA was kept at 1/4 and the molar ratio of CuBr2/PEG45-bPS was kept at 0.6/1, which are as same as those in ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization. As shown in Figure 6, PEG45-b-PS270 selfassembled into 30-60 nm nanoparticles (Figure 6A) and nanorods/nanospheres mixture (Figure 6B) in absence/presence of CuBr2/TPMA, and PEG45-b-PS278 formed 500 nm nano-spheres (Figure 6C) and flower-like vesicles (Figure 6D), respectively. By further comparing the nano-assemblies prepared at the four cases (Figures 6 and S6), it is found that, the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies prepared in the alcohol solvent in absence of and presence of TPMA are similar, and the nano-assemblies prepared in presence of CuBr2 and in presence of CuBr2 and TPMA are similar, and the two formers in absence of CuBr2 are much different from those in presence of CuBr2. From these, two conclusions are made. First, the two PEG45-b-PS samples with different Ð lead to different block copolymer morphologies, although their PS blocks have almost
constant DP. It is known as a general rule,6,62 with the increasing DP of the solvophobic block, amphiphilic diblock copolymer nanoassemblies change from nanospheres to nanorods and finally to vesicles. For block copolymer with a given molecular weight and with high Ð, there exists a fraction of high-molecular-weight polymer, and therefore they tend to form high order block copolymer nano-assemblies. Second, the additive of CuBr2 exerts great influence on block copolymer morphologies in their solution self-assemblies. It is supposed that the salting-out effect of the Cu salt may exert somewhat influence on the self-assembly of PEG45-bPS and therefore their morphology. Further study indicates that the morphology of the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies is correlative to the Cu salt concentration, and with Cu salt concentration increasing compact flower-like vesicles are formed (Figure S7).
Based on the above results, it is conclusively supposed that the relatively high Ð of PEG45-b-PS and the CuBr2/TPMA catalyst used in ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization may lead to the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies much different from those prepared via RAFT dispersion polymerization.

sections.heading: 3.4 Synthesis of more BCP nano-assemblies via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization
sections.text: Lastly, several other BCP nano-assemblies, e.g., the PEG45-bPMMA295 vesicles, the PHPMA29-b-PBzMA298 nanospheres and the nanospheres/nanorods mixture of PHPMA29-b-PMMA296, were synthesized by changing ATRP macroinitiators or monomers by targeting the DP of the solvophobic block at 300 (Figure S8). Note: see the polymer characterization in Table S1. This demonstrates that the present ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization is a promising method to synthesize BCP nano-assemblies.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
Block copolymer nano-assemblies were synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization employing the CuBr2/TPMA catalyst at a relatively low temperature of 45 C. By optimizing the polymerization conditions such as Cu catalyst concentration and polymerization temperature, controllable synthesis of block copolymer nano-assemblies of PEG-b-PS, PEG-b-PMMA, PHPMA-bPBzMA and PHPMA-b-PMMA was achieved. The typical PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies with the targeted DP of the PS block at 300 are compared with those synthesized via RAFT dispersion polymerization under other similar conditions. It is found that the PEG45-b-PS nano-assemblies synthesized via ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization have much complicated morphologies. Control experiments of dispersion polymerization and solution selfassemblies of prepared amphiphilic block copolymer with different Ð were performed, and the possible reasons why ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization and RAFT dispersion polymerization lead to different block copolymer nano-assemblies were discussed. It is believed that the high Ð of the synthesized BCPs and the salt of Cu catalyst used in ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization as well as the different nucleation of block copolymers lead to the difference between these two PISA formulations. This ICAR ATRP dispersion polymerization is demonstrated to be a promising method to prepare BCP nano-assemblies with complex morphology.
